channel.title: Wickerbox
channel.description: Adventures of an aerospace geek in Portland, Oregon.

item.title: Snow at the Tualatin Refuge
item.description:
Just the other night, the wetland was covered in geese; now it’s ice and slush.

The oak study area under snow.

The human-sized “eagle” nest they built back in summer is holding up nicely.

Continuing on through the Rock Creek study area and along the edge of the open wetland.

Lots of little birds foraging, geese passing overhead, and a hawk keeping an eye out.

There’s a viewing platform over the Tualatin River.

Following the creek around to the wetland. I spent a lot of time playing with lighting. Still not sure I have it.

I think the shapes made by leafless trees are great. Dendrophotography?

item.title: ISO Shutter Speed Example
item.description:
This is a shutter speed example using an X100S in snow at Tualatin Wildlife Refuge on Sunday, February 9th, 2014.

I wanted to get a sense for ISO, aperture, exposure time, and brightness of the resulting image. All photos were taken with +2 EV exposure bias with the mode on auto. I didn’t control for aperture. The results make sense because as the shutter is open longer, more light is captured.

ISO: 1/4000
Brightness: 9.75
Aperture: F2
Shutter Speed: 1/4096s = 244 microseconds

ISO: 1/2000s
Brightness: 9.94
Aperture: F2.8
Shutter Speed: 1/2048s = 488 microseconds

ISO: 1/1000s
Brightness: 9.87
Aperture: F4
Shutter Speed: 1/1024s = 976 microseconds

ISO: 1/500s
Brightness: 9.86
Aperture: F4.9
Shutter Speed: 1/512s = 1.95 milliseconds

ISO: 1/250s
Brightness: 9.74
Aperture: F7.2
Shutter Speed: 1/250s = 4 milliseconds

ISO: 1/125s
Brightness: 9.7
Aperture: F9.8
Shutter Speed: 1/128s = 7.81 milliseconds

ISO: 1/60s
Brightness: 9.52
Aperture: F13
Shutter Speed: 1/64s = 15.6 milliseconds

ISO: 1/30s
Brightness: 9.4
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/32s = 31.25 milliseconds

ISO: 1/15s
Brightness: 9.4
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/16s = 62.5 milliseconds

ISO: 1/8s
Brightness: 9.32
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/8s = 125 milliseconds

ISO: 1/4s
Brightness: 9.54
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/4s = 250 milliseconds

ISO: 1/2s
Brightness: 9.54
Aperture: F16
Shutter Speed: 1/2s = 500 milliseconds

item.title: Exposure Example
item.description:
This is an exposure example using an X100S in snow at Tualatin Wildlife Refuge on Sunday, February 9th, 2014.

I wanted to get a sense for ISO, aperture, exposure time, and brightness of the resulting image when stepping from -2 to +2 EV exposure bias with the mode on auto. I didn’t control for aperture. I didn’t control for anything, really, I’m just playing around. The results make sense because as the shutter is open longer, more light is captured.

ISO: 1/950s
Brightness: 8.94
Aperture: F11
Shutter Speed: 1/969s = 1.03 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: -2 EV

ISO: 1/850s
Brightness: 8.79
Aperture: F8
Shutter Speed: 1/873s = 1.14 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: -1 EV

ISO: 1/900s
Brightness: 8.83
Aperture: F5.7
Shutter Speed: 1/891s = 1.12 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: 0 EV

ISO: 1/640s
Brightness: 9.37
Aperture: F5.7
Shutter Speed: 1/648s = 1.54 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: +1 EV

ISO: 1/450s
Brightness: 9.87
Aperture: F5.7
Shutter Speed: 1/458s = 2.18 milliseconds
Exposure Bias: +2 EV

item.title: Oven Control Board v2
item.description:
I worked with Tung as part of the ME capstone team at Portland State to update the oven controller Arduino shield I made last week. Tung had already updated the Eagle schematic so this time for me it was just layout, routing, and basic soldering. I fixed the one via problem but then promptly made the same mistake on the other set of headers, so I delivered the board last night and it should work fine but the soldering was trickier than I’d like.

I’m still so spoiled by having OSHPark. The only Gerbers I give our lab’s LPKF router are the Top Layer, Bottom Layer, Board Outline, and Unplated Drill. No silkscreen. I could solder mask but I haven’t. Maybe next time. I used materials and headers I had on hand but even through OSHPark it’d be just under $30 for three boards.

Here are the schematic, layout, and final photos. Eagle files are on the Github repo.

item.title: 1 Feb 2014
item.description:
I was a little bummed this morning that January’s over and I don’t have any other hardware stuff to post about but I realized that I’ve been super busy doing, you know, work for which I’m paid and can’t talk about. On the hobby hacking side, I’ve done plenty of work this month between the oven controller, a couple of GPS RF board design reviews, the DxWiFi test, and my BJJ habit. I’ve also had four sessions of EPL managing where other people came in to work on stuff.

One of my biggest reasons for having the site is to remind myself that I do things by posting pictures of the stuff I do. I tend to forget and then blame myself for being Not Productive Enough.

So looking back, I’m delighted to remember that I had a really enjoyable January.

item.title: 28 Jan 2014
item.description:
My library flow for Eagle is to work out of a single directory called ~/.eagle and have all my libraries, scripts, etc. to be in there. Anything that would be used by multiple designs.

I never, ever, ever use the epf files and I’ve yet to meet anybody who does.

To start a new design, I make a repo on Github and clone it to my dev machine. I create a schematic and start working. At some point I’ll make the board and work on that. Any changes to libraries happens in that default directory.

When I’m reading to commit, I use the Eagle export function to create multiple library files into a local folder called ‘lbr’ or ‘libraries’ so anybody who forks the repo has all the parts they need.

When I git pull, I always check if I got updated libraries and I’ll wrap them back into my default library. I’m pretty sure I’m running the risk of losing work in the overwriting/copying process but I’m kind of stuck on what to do about it, except be very careful.

Eagle’s libraries are basically just frustrating as hell.

item.title: Oven Control Board v1
item.description:
An ME capstone team at Portland State is working on an oven so we can cure our own composites. It’s awesome. This oven control board was a five-day project that came out of nowhere this week on Tuesday and which I delivered on Sunday.

Tung, their electrical person, already had the design figured out and working with breadboard components and an Arduino. What he really wanted was an Arduino shield so we met, looked at what he had, and figured out how we’d put it on the right footprint. This is the first time I’d been able to sit with someone who was new to Eagle and really explain what makes a decent schematic, so it’s pretty cool to see how much I’ve learned in just a couple of years.

The layout was constrained by the shield but even moreso by our plan to use the LPKF router. It had to be a two-layer board that didn’t have plated through-holes or vias. I managed to put all the traces except one on the bottom layer because all the components get soldered on the bottom side (they’re all through-hole) and then I just made that a much wider polygon fill and dropped vias to get the top-trace signal connected down below.

Unfortunately, Arduino shields sit on top of the Arduino so I had to drop an extra via on each pad of the 0.1" headers so copper wire could be slid through and squashed, essentially plating them myself.

The final product doesn’t look too shabby. Well, I take that back — the isolation on the LPKF is so tiny (even at the double-width!) that I’m terrified of putting too much solder on each pin and shorting it outside the pad. This is really crappy soldering but I ohmed everything out so electrically the joints are fine.

Definitely I’ve been spoiled with OSHPark and $5/sq in board with plated through-holes and solder mask.

The libraries and everything are all up in the oven-controller Github repo.

item.title: 27 Jan 2014
item.description:
I got super busy with work but then this week have done a ton of rocket club stuff. The GPS RF board is still in design reviews but I think we’ve got the RF side figured out.

I finished an oven control board PCB layout and got it routed for the oven team. All the files are in the Github repo.

We went up to Rocky Butte and shot wifi packets to Council Crest with the DxWiFi team.

I think running around at full speed finally let the cold I’ve been fighting hit me because I was already feeling like crap on Sunday and then I ended up sleeping til the afternoon today. Ugh. Tomorrow will be better.

I just got the email that says my Foxcar control board is in the mail so I guess I know what I’m doing this weekend…

item.title: 6 Jan 2014
item.description:
Beautiful day doing flight test of our cameras for work.

I’ve been looking at putting the Robot Operating System on the STM32F Discovery Board so I took a brief detour through basic toolchain review. A couple nice links are these at eLinux – Toolchains and thing2.

In general, paraphrasing from the article, I need disk space, decent CPU and memory, recent gcc compiler and GNU build utilities for the sort of stuff I do.

I’m prototyping on ARM processors so I build arm-none-eabi and newlib, which successfully can build the libraries; works with FreeRTOS, ChibiOS, and ROS; and can make binaries for bare metal (no OS) software. I’m not developing for embedded Linux targets so I don’t have to build against glibc. I’m not sure what an embedded Linux target really is, though.

Having an arm-x-eabi means it’s for ARM with the ARM standard EABI.

  • arm-none-eabi means it’s not for a specific OS or build
  • arm-psas-eabi means it expects the PSAS environment
  • arm-linux-eabi is designed to be used to build programs with glibc under Linux
